block.p: ATTRACTIONS
Museums and Sites

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY, Central Park West and 79th Street. The Arthur Ross Terrace, a new one-acre public space with ginkgo and pagoda trees, has recently opened, with the same hours as the museum. ''The Butterfly Conservatory: Tropical Butterflies Alive in Winter,'' live multicolored butterflies from Africa, Asia and the Americas on view in the rain forest of the Butterfly Conservatory; through May 28. Tickets, which include museum admission: $15; $11 for students and the elderly; $9 for children, 2 to 12; under 2 free. Advance tickets: (212) 769-5200. ''Fighting Dinosaurs: New Discoveries From Mongolia,'' featuring one of the most famous fossil finds in the world; through Oct. 29. ''Mongolia Observed: Photographs Present and Past,'' featuring 40 color images by Robert Peck and black-and-white photographs from the 1920's and 30's by the explorer Ray Chapman Andrews. Through Dec. 30. Imax films are ''To Be an Astronaut'' and ''Dolphins.'' In the Imax Theater tonight and tomorrow night at 9, ''Laser Aerosmith in 3-D''; at 10, ''Laser Led Zeppelin.'' Laser show tickets: $12. Museum hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 8:45 p.m. Admission (suggested donation): $10 for adults; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $6 for children. Combination tickets are available. Information: (212) 769-5100; advance tickets: (212) 769-5200.

AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This 333,500-square-foot, seven-floor, 120-foot-high exhibition and research center includes the new Hayden Planetarium, the Cullman Hall of the Universe and the Gottesman Hall of Planet Earth. The Hayden Planetarium contains the Space Theater, presenting ''Passport to the Universe,'' and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of the universe. ''Starry Nights: Fridays Under the Sphere,'' with the Jimmy Heath Quartet, from 6 to 8 p.m., with cash bar and tapas. ''Full Moon: Apollo Mission Photographs of the Lunar Landscape,'' from NASA's Apollo missions to the moon; through January. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays to 8:45 p.m. Space shows run throughout the day. Suggested admission to the American Museum of Natural History, which includes the Rose Center: $10; for students and the elderly, $7.50; children 12 and under, $6; under 2, free. Admission to the museum, the Rose Center and the Hayden Planetarium space show: $19; students and the elderly, $14; children 12 and under, $11.50; under 2, free. Information: (212) 769-5100. Reservations: (212) 769-5200.

HISTORIC RICHMONDTOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmondtown. Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., ''Old Home Day: The Autumn Celebration,'' including a bluegrass festival featuring Alvin Breeden and the Virginia Cutups, Tri-County Ramblers and Home Cookin', along with demonstrations in blacksmithing, gunsmithing, tinsmithing and candlemaking. Admission: $5; $2.50 for the elderly and children 6 to 17; free for under 6. Guided tours are available. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; the elderly, children 6 to 18 and students, $2.50; 5 and under, free. Information: (718) 351-1611.

MUSEUM OF JEWISH HERITAGE: A LIVING MEMORIAL TO THE HOLOCAUST, 18 First Place, at West Street and Battery Place, Battery Park City, Lower Manhattan. Artifacts, documents, photographs, videos and film clips are included in exhibitions on the Holocaust and on Jewish life before and after World War II. ''Children of a Vanished World: Photographs by Roman Vishniac,'' through next Friday. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m.; Fridays and the eves of Jewish holidays, 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.; closed Saturdays. Admission: $7; students and the elderly, $5; children 5 and under, free. Tickets can be bought in advance through Ticketmaster, (212) 307-4007, or by calling the museum on the day of the visit, (212) 945-0039. Information: (212) 509-6130.

MUSEUM OF TELEVISION AND RADIO, 25 West 52nd Street, Manhattan. A collection of taped radio and television broadcasts and exhibitions in other media, including drawings, posters and photographs. ''Madison Avenue Goes to Washington: The History of Presidential Campaign Advertising,'' historically significant presidential commercials created between 1952 and 1996; Tuesdays through Sundays at 2 p.m. through Nov. 12. ''Monster in the Box: Horror on Television,'' a series focusing on five decades of the genre; through Sunday the screenings will highlight the work of Boris Karloff; Fridays at 7 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays at 4 p.m.; Thursdays at 6 p.m.; through Dec. 10. Museum hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays until 8 p.m. On Fridays the theater is open until 9. Admission: $6; students and the elderly, $4; 12 and under, $3. Information: (212) 621-6800.

NEW-YORK HISTORICAL SOCIETY, 170 Central Park West, near 77th Street. ''Jenny Lind: The Swedish Nightingale in America,'' through Dec. 30. ''Inventing the Skyline: The Architecture of Cass Gilbert (1859-1934),'' through Jan. 21. Tomorrow at 10 a.m., a symposium on the exhibition ''Inventing the Skyline,'' including the authors of the catalog printed by Columbia University Press. The Actors Company Theater will present a production of ''First Lady,'' by Katharine Dayton and George S. Kaufman. Performances are tonight at 8, gala opening; Sunday at 2:30 p.m.; Monday night at 7:30. Tickets: $15. Reservations: (212) 645-8228. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; students and the elderly, $3; 12 and under, free. Information: (212) 873-3400.
Gardens

BROOKLYN BOTANIC GARDEN, 1000 Washington Avenue, Crown Heights. More than 12,000 kinds of plants from around the world are displayed on 52 acres. The Japanese Hill and Pond Garden is open and guided tours are available. Free tours Saturdays and Sundays at 1 p.m.; meet at the Visitors Center. Admission: $3; $1.50 for students and the elderly; free for children 15 and under; free on Tuesdays, except holidays; free from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 8 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and holidays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m. The conservatory closes 30 minutes before the grounds. Information: (718) 623-7200.

NEW YORK BOTANICAL GARDEN, Southern Boulevard and 200th Street, Bedford Park, the Bronx. The grounds include more than 47 specialty gardens and plant collections. The fall flower exhibition, including asters, sedums, fall-blooming roses and beech foliage, through mid-November. Scarecrow exhibition through Nov. 5. Saturdays and Sundays at 12:30 p.m., 90-minute bird and butterfly walks. Tomorrow, ''Get Up and Garden Day'' features workshops, fall gardening tips and tours. On Sunday at 3 p.m., the Bronx Arts Ensemble performs works by Brahms, Debussy and Loevendie. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays and Monday holidays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Botanical garden admission: $3; students and the elderly, $2; children 2 to 12, $1; under 2, free. Conservatory admission: $3.50; students and the elderly, $2.50; children 2 to 12, $2; under 2, free. Grounds admission free for all on Wednesdays and from 10 a.m. to noon on Saturdays. There are combination packages. Parking: $5. Combination tickets are available. Information: (718) 817-8700.

STATEN ISLAND BOTANICAL GARDEN, 1000 Richmond Terrace, Livingston. The garden covers 83 acres. Hours: daily, 8 a.m. to dusk. Free admission to the grounds. The one-acre New York Chinese Scholars' Garden is open. ''Connie Gretz's Secret Garden,'' a walled garden with a formal maze, including a castle and a moat drawbridge, adjacent to the New York Chinese Scholars' Garden, with the same hours. Admission to ''Secret Garden,'' $2 adults, $1 a child; adults are free with a child. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission to the Chinese Scholars' Garden:: $5; $3 for students, the elderly and children under 12; under 1, free. Information: (718) 273-8200.
RECREATION

SIXTH ''TOUR DE BRONX,'' a ride of 25 or 40 miles through the borough that will pass such sites as Charlotte Gardens, St. Ann's Church, the Mott Haven Historic District and Co-op City. On Sunday with two start times: at 10 a.m. in front of the New York Botanical Garden stop on Metro North, at Southern Boulevard and 200th Street; and at 10:45 a.m. in front of the Bronx County Courthouse, 851 Grand Concourse, at 161st Street. Free; helmets will be given to the first 150 children 14 and younger to check in at either of the starting locations. Sponsored by Transportation Alternatives and the office of the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer. Information: (718) 590-2766.

STATEN ISLAND HALF MARATHON. A 13.1-mile run. Begins Sunday at 9:40 a.m. at Richmond Terrace outdoor the Staten Island Ferry Terminal and ends at Von Briesen Park. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Advance registration fee: $17, $12 for club members; $10 for junior and senior club members. Race day registration: $22; $15 for members; $12 for junior and senior club members. Information: (212) 860-4455.

NEW YORK TERRY FOX RUN, Central Park. A five-kilometer run. Tomorrow at 9:30 a.m. at Tavern on the Green, West 67th Street and Central Park Drive. Registration fee, $15; free for children under 12. Proceeds benefit the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Information: (212) 371-8855.

KURT STEINER 5K, Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. A five-kilometer run. Sunday, with start times at 11:30 a.m. for women, noon for men and 12:30 p.m. for children. Starts at Broadway and West 252nd Street. Sponsored by the New York Road Runners Club. Registration fee, $3; $2 for children. Information: (212) 860-4455.
EVENTS

PARK AVENUE ANTIQUES SHOW, Wallace Hall, Park Avenue and 84th Street. Today and tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission, $10; proceeds from ticket sales benefit the Church of St. Ignatius Loyola. Information: (212) 288-3588.
GRAMERCY PARK ANTIQUES SHOW, 69th Regiment Armory, 68 Lexington Avenue at 26th Street. Today, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission, $10. Information: (212) 255-0020.

''THE ITALIAN-AMERICAN BOOK,'' Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 104th Street, Manhattan. A two-day conference devoted to the history and future of books by Italian-American writers; participants include scholars, writers, teachers, publishers and booksellers. Today and tomorrow, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Sponsored by the Italian-American Writers Association. Admission for both days, $30; $25 for museum and association members. Information: (212) 534-1672, extension 257.

''WOMEN AND THE AMERICAN REVOLUTION,'' King Manor Museum, Jamaica Avenue, between 150th and 153rd Streets, Queens. A discussion on the role of women during the Revolutionary War led by Carol Berkin, a historian. Tomorrow at 1 p.m. Fee, $5. Also at the museum tomorrow and Sunday from noon to 4 p.m., a free house tour and party marking the 231st anniversary of the birth of Mary Alsop King, wife of Rufus King, a signer of the Constitution. Information: (718) 206-0545.

''AN EVENING WITH W. B. YEATS AND JOHN QUINN,'' Irish Repertory Theater, 132 West 22nd Street, Chelsea. A short play about the writer and the lawyer who was his patron. Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m. Tickets, $16 ($8 for students and the elderly). A discussion about the two men will precede Sunday's performance at 6:30 p.m. (admission, $4; $2 for students and the elderly); tickets to both events, $20 ($10 for students and the elderly). Information and reservations: (212) 727-2737.
ON THE STREET

''CRAFTS ON COLUMBUS,'' Columbus Avenue from 77th to 81st Streets and the sidewalk along 81st Street from Columbus Avenue to the American Museum of Natural History, Manhattan. Tomorrow and Sunday, 10 a.m. to 5:30 p.m. Also Oct. 21 and 22, same hours. Sponsored by the American Arts and Crafts Alliance.
OCTOBERFEST, Public School 6, East 82nd Street between Park and Madison Avenues. Tomorrow, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.

WEST FOURTH STREET UNITED METHODIST FESTIVAL, from Avenue of the Americas to University Place Streets, Greenwich Village. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. Sponsored by the United Methodist Church of Greenwich Village.
AUTUMN FAIR, Irving Place from 14th to 20th Streets, Manhattan. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Gramercy Park Block Association.
P.S. 11 STREET FAIR, 21st Street between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Manhattan. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 4 p.m.
NINTH UPPER BROADWAY FALL FESTIVAL, 110th to 118th Streets, Morningside Heights. Tomorrow, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by the Upper West Side Recycling Center.
AVENUE OF THE AMERICAS FAMILY EXPO, from 42nd to 57th Streets. Sunday, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Sponsored by Global Role Models.
ROCKY SULLIVAN STREET FAIR, 28th Street from Third to Lexington Avenues. Sunday, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m. WALKING TOURS

''ROOSEVELT ISLAND'' visits the neighborhood and its landmarks. Meets today at 11 a.m. at the Roosevelt Island tramway at Second Avenue and 59th Street, upstairs at the token booth. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $10 plus $3 tram fare; $8 for students, the elderly and society members. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''NEW YORK IN THE TIME OF WASHINGTON IRVING,'' Lower Manhattan. A look at how events in the social and professional life of the writer and his contemporaries mirror the history of the city. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. on the northeast corner of Lafayette and East Fourth Streets. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for society members and members of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''MANHATTAN MURDER MYSTERIES'' tours Manhattan's most famous crime scenes. Meets tomorrow at 2 p.m. in front of the Park Central Hotel, Seventh Avenue at 56th Street. Fee: $10. Street Smarts N.Y. Information: (212) 969-8262.
''MARK TWAIN'S NEW YORK.'' Sites of importance in the writer's life. Tomorrow at 1 p.m. Fee, $15. Sponsored by the Cooper Union. Information and meeting place: (212) 353-4195.

''THE ANONYMOUS SCULPTURES OF BROOKLYN HEIGHTS.'' Visits buildings adorned with mythical figures. Meets tomorrow at 11 a.m. at the Brooklyn Public Library, Cadman Plaza West at Tillary Street. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for center members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 701.

''HELL'S KITCHEN HIKE'' tours the Midtown area now known as Clinton. Meets tomorrow at 3 p.m. on the northeast corner of Eighth Avenue and 48th Street. Fee: $5. Sponsored by Adventure on a Shoestring. Information: (212) 265-2663.

''HAWK WATCH AT FORT TILDEN,'' Brooklyn. A walk in search of these birds of prey, with glimpses of the others mammals, snakes and insects that inhabit the area. Meets on Sunday at 8:20 at the arch at Grand Army Plaza and at 10 a.m. at the Fort Tilden Center. Sponsored by the Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment. Fee, $8; $6 for Center members; $5 for students and the elderly. Information: (718) 788-8500, extension 401.

''OFF TO VISTA HILL, Green-Wood Cemetery, Brooklyn. Jeff Richman, author of ''Brooklyn's Green-Wood Cemetery: New York's Buried Treasure,'' will lead a walk that will touch on figures including Boss Tweed and the Steinway family. Meets tomorrow at 1 p.m. at the main entrance of Green-Wood Cemetery, 25th Street and Fifth Avenue, Greenwood Heights, Brooklyn. Fee: $10. Information: (631) 549-4891.

''NOSHWALK IN ASTORIA,'' Queens. With stops at various ethnic restaurants and markets and an optional visit to the Isamu Noguchi Garden Museum. Meets Sunday at 11 a.m. at the park at 30th Avenue and 30th Street. Fee, $14, excluding lunch. Sponsored by NoshWalks. Information: (212) 222-2243.

''DOWNTOWN DECO: DEVELOPMENT AND DECORATION IN THE JAZZ AGE,'' Lower Manhattan. A look at the decorations found on banks, corporate buildings and clubs, along with a stop in the lobby of the Cities Service Building on Wall Street. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. on the southwest corner of Fulton and Williams Streets. Sponsored by the Municipal Art Society. Fee, $15; $12 for society members and members of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. Information: (212) 935-3960.

''THE HIDDEN CHARMS OF CHELSEA: SEMINARY, BROWNSTONES AND SHOCKING INHABITANTS'' traces the development of the area from its beginnings as Clement Clarke Moore's 100-acre farm. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. at the General Theological Seminary, Ninth Avenue and 20th Street. Fee, $12. Sponsored by Joyce Gold History Tours of New York. Information: (212) 242-5762.

''LOWER EAST SIDE I: RADICAL JEWS.'' A walk past sites associated with turn-of-the-century activists like Abraham Cahan, a founder of The Jewish Daily Forward, and Sidney Hillman, a labor adviser and the founder of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America, who spent time at the original buildings on Henry Street, off Pitt Street, where the Henry Street Settlement was founded. Sponsored by Radical Walking Tours. Meets Sunday at 1 p.m. in front of the old Jewish Daily Forward Building at 175 East Broadway. Fee: $10. Information:(718) 492-0069.

BROOKLYN BRIDGE TALK AND WALK. Discusses the Roebling family, instrumental in the building of the bridge, and the importance of the structure itself. Meets Sunday at 2 p.m. inside Blimpie's, 38 Park Row, Lower Manhattan. Fee: $12. Sponsored by Dr. Phil: New York Talks and Walks. Information: (888) 377-4455.

HARLEM GOSPEL TOUR. A gospel service, church lunch and stops at other historic churches. Meets on Sunday at 11 a.m. on the northwest corner of Lenox Avenue and 135th Street. Fee: $20. Sponsored by Harlem Heritage Tours. Information: (212) 280-7888.
